claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 106:
(1) A subagent represents the principal with respect to acts within the scope of the authority thereof.
(2) A subagent has the same rights and obligations as an agent in relation to the principal and third parties within the scope of that subagent's authority.
(Abuse of Authority to Represent)



        Conclusion:
        A guardian of adult may not appoint its sub-agent unless there is an unavoidable reason to do so..'''
argument: The premises provided in Article 106 do not address the specific conditions under which a guardian of an adult may appoint a sub-agent. The conclusion that a guardian may not appoint a sub-agent unless there is an unavoidable reason to do so is not logically entailed by the given premises, as the premises only discuss the general rights and obligations of subagents and do not specify any restrictions on the appointment of subagents by guardians of adults.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 353:
A pledgee of movables may, if the pledged thing is usurped, recover the same solely by filing an action for recovery of possession.
(Enforcement of Pledges on Movables)



        Conclusion:
        If the possession of the pledgee of a pledge on movable property is stolen by a third party, the pledgee can demand the return based on the pledge..'''
argument: The conclusion overstates the remedy provided in Article 353. The article specifies that the pledgee may recover the pledged thing by filing an action for recovery of possession, not by directly demanding the return of the property from the third party. The process of recovery is more formal and requires legal action, rather than a simple demand for return.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 103:
An agent who has no specifically defined authority has the authority to perform the following acts only:
(i) acts of preservation; and
(ii) acts with the purpose of using or improving a thing or right that is the subject matter of the agency, to the extent that this does not change the nature of that thing or right.
(Appointment of Subagents by Agents)



        Conclusion:
        An agent who has no specified authority shall have the authority only to do the acts of preservation..'''
argument: The conclusion is too narrow as it only mentions 'acts of preservation' but omits 'acts with the purpose of using or improving a thing or right that is the subject matter of the agency, to the extent that this does not change the nature of that thing or right.' This omission means the conclusion does not fully capture the scope of authority granted by Article 103.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 646:
(1) A mandatary must deliver to the mandator monies and other things received during the course of administering the mandated business. The same applies to fruits the mandatary has reaped.
(2) A mandatary must transfer to the mandator rights that the mandatary has acquired in the mandatary's own name on behalf of the mandator.
(Mandatary's Responsibility for Consumption of Monies)



        Conclusion:
        The mandatary is not obligated to deliver to the mandator civil fruits reaped during the course of administering the mandated business..'''
argument: The conclusion contradicts the premise stated in Article 646(1), which explicitly states that a mandatary must deliver to the mandator monies and other things received during the course of administering the mandated business, including fruits the mandatary has reaped. Therefore, the premises do not logically entail the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 140:
When a period is provided for in days, weeks, months, or years, the first day of the period is not included in the computation; provided, however, that this does not apply when the period commences at twelve midnight.
(Expiration of Period)



        Conclusion:
        If an agreement is made at 3:00 p.m. on May 16 of a given year that the obligation will be fulfilled within one week, the period commences at twelve midnight of the same day, which does not fall on Sunday, holiday as provided in the Act on National Holidays, or any other holiday..'''
argument: The conclusion incorrectly applies Article 140. According to the statute, the first day of the period is not included in the computation unless the period commences at twelve midnight. Since the agreement is made at 3:00 p.m. on May 16, the period should start from May 17, not from twelve midnight of May 16. Therefore, the conclusion does not logically follow from the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 487:
If there is an instrument evidencing a claim and the person making the performance has made full performance, that person may demand the return of the instrument.
(Appropriation of One Payment or Delivery among Two or More Obligations Requiring the Same Kind of Payment or Delivery)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where there is any instrument which evidences the claim for wages, the borrower may assert the fact that he/she will make a payment by returning and exchanging the instrument when attempting to make the performance has completed his/her entire performance..'''
argument: The conclusion incorrectly assumes that the 'borrower' can assert the return of the instrument after completing the performance. However, Article 487 specifies that the 'person making the performance' (which could be the debtor, not necessarily the borrower) has the right to demand the return of the instrument. The argument conflates the roles of the borrower and the person making the performance, which may not be the same entity.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 300:
The exercise of a right of retention does not preclude the running of extinctive prescription of claims.
(Extinction of Rights of Retention by Provision of Security)



        Conclusion:
        The extinctive prescription of the claim secured by the right of retention does not run while the holder of the right of retention exercises the right of retention and retains the subject matter..'''
argument: The conclusion contradicts the premise provided in Article 300. According to the premise, the exercise of a right of retention does not preclude the running of extinctive prescription of claims. This means that even if the right of retention is exercised, the extinctive prescription of the claim can still run. Therefore, the conclusion that the extinctive prescription does not run while the right of retention is exercised is not logically entailed by the premise.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 655:
The grounds of termination of mandate may not be asserted against the other party unless the other party was notified of or knew of the same.
(Quasi-Mandate)



        Conclusion:
        Regardless of the other party's knowledge, the grounds of termination of mandate may not be asserted against the other party unless the other party was notified of the same..'''
argument: The conclusion incorrectly adds a condition regarding the other party's knowledge, which is not present in the original Article 655. The article specifies that the grounds of termination may not be asserted unless the other party was notified or knew of the grounds. The conclusion omits the 'or knew' part, which means it does not fully capture the conditions stated in the premise.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 371:
If there is a default with respect to a claim secured by a mortgage, the mortgage extends to the fruits of the mortgaged immovables derived after the default.
(Mutatis Mutandis Application of Provisions on Right of Retention)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where a mortgagor lease land which is a subject matter of the mortgage to a person, the mortgage shall extend to the rent without a default with respect to a claim secured by the mortgage..'''
argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premises provided. Article 371 specifies that the mortgage extends to the fruits of the mortgaged immovables only after a default has occurred. The conclusion, however, asserts that the mortgage extends to the rent even without a default, which is not supported by the premise. Therefore, the argument is not valid as the conclusion is not a necessary logical consequence of the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 244:
If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the movables united by accession, the owner of each movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession.
(Mixture)



        Conclusion:
        If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the joined movables, based on a demand by one or several owners of each of the movables, the owners shall be determined by court..'''
argument: The conclusion that 'the owners shall be determined by court' does not logically follow from the premises provided in Article 244. The statute specifies that in cases where the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made, the owners co-own the composite thing in proportion to the value of their respective contributions. It does not state that a court must determine the ownership, only that the co-ownership is based on the value of the contributions. Therefore, the conclusion introduces an additional step (court determination) that is not supported by the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 406:
If the subject matter of the claim is to be determined by a choice being made from among more than one performance, the right to choose belongs to the obligor.
(Exercise of Right to Choose)



        Conclusion:
        If the subject of the claim is to be identified by way of choice among more than one performance, the right to make the choice shall vest in the obligor as long as there is no special provision..'''
argument: The conclusion is not entirely valid because it introduces a condition ('as long as there is no special provision') that is not explicitly stated in the premise (Article 406). The premise does not mention any exceptions or conditions under which the right to choose might not vest in the obligor, thus the conclusion adds an additional constraint that is not supported by the given premise.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 632:
A contract for work become effective when one of the parties promises to complete work and the other party promises to pay remuneration for the outcome of the work.
(Timing of Payment of Remuneration)



        Conclusion:
        The contractor may not claim his/her remuneration without the specified consent of remuneration amount..'''
argument: The conclusion that 'the contractor may not claim his/her remuneration without the specified consent of remuneration amount' is not directly supported by the premise provided in Article 632. The premise states that a contract for work becomes effective when both parties agree to the terms, including the promise to complete work and the promise to pay remuneration. However, it does not explicitly state that the contractor cannot claim remuneration without a specified consent of the remuneration amount. The premise only indicates that the contract is formed upon mutual agreement, but does not address the conditions under which remuneration can be claimed.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 134:
A juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor.
(Effect of Arrival of Assigned Time)



        Conclusion:
        A juristic act which is subject to a condition precedent shall be void if the condition is dependent upon the will of the obligor..'''
argument: The conclusion overgeneralizes the premise. Article 134 specifically states that a juridical act is void if the condition is dependent 'only' upon the intention of the obligor. The conclusion, however, omits this critical qualifier and states that the act is void if the condition is dependent 'upon the will of the obligor,' which could be interpreted more broadly and may include scenarios where the condition is not solely dependent on the obligor's intention. This broad interpretation is not supported by the premise.
